1: <sup>1</sup> The preparations of the heart in man, and the answer of the tongue, is from the LORD.
2: <sup>2</sup> All the ways of a man are clean in his own eyes; but the LORD weigheth the spirits.
3: <sup>3</sup> Commit thy works unto the LORD, and thy thoughts shall be established.
4: <sup>4</sup> The LORD hath made all things for himself: yea, even the wicked for the day of evil.
5: <sup>5</sup> Every one that is proud in heart is an abomination to the LORD: though hand join in hand, he shall not be unpunished.
6: <sup>6</sup> By mercy and truth iniquity is purged: and by the fear of the LORD men depart from evil.
7: <sup>7</sup> When a man’s ways please the LORD, he maketh even his enemies to be at peace with him.
8: <sup>8</sup> Better is a little with righteousness than great revenues without right.
9: <sup>9</sup> A man’s heart deviseth his way: but the LORD directeth his steps.
10: <sup>10</sup> A divine sentence is in the lips of the king: his mouth transgresseth not in judgment.
11: <sup>11</sup> A just weight and balance are the LORD’s: all the weights of the bag are his work.
12: <sup>12</sup> It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness: for the throne is established by righteousness.
13: <sup>13</sup> Righteous lips are the delight of kings; and they love him that speaketh right.
14: <sup>14</sup> The wrath of a king is as messengers of death: but a wise man will pacify it.
15: <sup>15</sup> In the light of the king’s countenance is life; and his favour is as a cloud of the latter rain.
16: <sup>16</sup> How much better is it to get wisdom than gold! and to get understanding rather to be chosen than silver!
17: <sup>17</sup> The highway of the upright is to depart from evil: he that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.
18: <sup>18</sup> Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall.
19: <sup>19</sup> Better it is to be of an humble spirit with the lowly, than to divide the spoil with the proud.
20: <sup>20</sup> He that handleth a matter wisely shall find good: and whoso trusteth in the LORD, happy is he.
21: <sup>21</sup> The wise in heart shall be called prudent: and the sweetness of the lips increaseth learning.
22: <sup>22</sup> Understanding is a wellspring of life unto him that hath it: but the instruction of fools is folly.
23: <sup>23</sup> The heart of the wise teacheth his mouth, and addeth learning to his lips.
24: <sup>24</sup> Pleasant words are as an honeycomb, sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.
25: <sup>25</sup> There is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death.
26: <sup>26</sup> He that laboureth laboureth for himself; for his mouth craveth it of him.
27: <sup>27</sup> An ungodly man diggeth up evil: and in his lips there is as a burning fire.
28: <sup>28</sup> A froward man soweth strife: and a whisperer separateth chief friends.
29: <sup>29</sup> A violent man enticeth his neighbour, and leadeth him into the way that is not good.
30: <sup>30</sup> He shutteth his eyes to devise froward things: moving his lips he bringeth evil to pass.
31: <sup>31</sup> The hoary head is a crown of glory, if it be found in the way of righteousness.
32: <sup>32</sup> He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city.
33: <sup>33</sup> The lot is cast into the lap; but the whole disposing thereof is of the LORD.
